Module kivakit.core
Package com.telenav.kivakit.core.ensure

Class Ensure

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.kivakit.core.ensure.Ensure
public class Ensure extends Object
A class for providing flexibility and consistency in the checking of states and parameters. There are multiple kinds of validation tools available in the Java environment, including manual checks, exceptions, assertions, loggers, Objects.require(), JUnit assertions and others. This class provides a consistent, abstracted interface to this functionality, such that all messages are formatted using Formatter and the kind of failure reporting can be changed at runtime for different classes of failures.

An application can specify what kind of reporting it wants by calling Failure.reporter(Class, FailureReporter), passing in the class of failure and the FailureReporter that should be used to report it.

Failure Types

  • Failure - A generic failure message reported by fail(String, Object...)
  • EnsureProblem - An ensure failure reported by one of the ensure() methods
  • Unsupported - An unsupported operation reported by unsupported(String, Object...)

Validation Reporters

The FailureReporter methods used to report Ensure failures:

  • FailureReporter.asserting() - Fails with a Java assertion
  • FailureReporter.logging() - Logs the failure
  • Listener.emptyListener() - Does nothing
  • Listener.throwingListener() - Throws an exception

Default Reporting

All failure types are linked to the FailureReporter by default.

Ensure

  • ensure(boolean)
  • ensure(boolean, String, Object...)
  • ensure(Supplier, String, Object...)
  • ensure(boolean, Throwable, String, Object...)
  • ensureFalse(boolean)
  • ensureFalse(boolean, String, Object...)
  • fail(String, Object...)

Ensure Null

  • ensureNull(Object)
  • ensureNull(Object, String, Object...)
  • ensureNotNull(Object)
  • ensureNotNull(Object, String, Object...)

Ensure Equality

  • ensureEqual(Object, Object)
  • ensureEqual(Object, Object, String, Object...)
  • ensureNotEqual(Object, Object)
  • ensureNotEqual(Object, Object, String, Object...)
  • ensureEqualArray(Object[], Object[])
  • ensureEqualArray(byte[], byte[])

Ensure Behavior

  • ensureBroadcastsProblem(Broadcaster, Consumer)
  • ensureBroadcastsNoProblem(Broadcaster, Consumer)
  • ensureThrows(Runnable)

Ensure Math

  • ensureZero(Number)
  • ensureNonZero(Number)
  • ensureClose(Duration, Duration)
  • ensureClose(Number, Number, int)
  • ensureBetweenExclusive(long, long, long)
  • ensureBetweenInclusive(long, long, long)
  • ensureBetweenInclusive(long, long, long, String, Object...)
  • ensureBetweenExclusive(long, long, long, String, Object...)
  • ensureBetween(double, double, double)

Examples:

 ensure(x < 100);
 ensure(x < 100, "The value $ is not less than 100", x);
 ensure(() -> computeX() < 100);
 ensure(() -> isValid(), "$ is not valid", name());
 ensureEqual(a, b, "Point $ is not equal to point $", a, b);

Fail Methods

Methods are provided to report outright failures with a Failure message:

  • fail() - Fails with a generic message
  • fail(String, Object...) - Fails with the formatted message
  • fail(Throwable, String, Object...) - Fails with the formatted message

Unsupported Methods

Unsupported operations are reported with an Unsupported message:

  • unsupported() - Reports an unsupported operation with an Unsupported message
  • unsupported(String, Object...) - Reports an unsupported operation with an Unsupported message

Exception-Throwing Methods

Methods are also provided to throw two common exceptions:

  • illegalState(String, Object...) - Throws a formatted IllegalStateException
  • illegalArgument(String, Object...) - Throws a formatted IllegalArgumentException

Examples:

 unsupported();
 illegalArgument("$ should be between $ and $", x, minimum, maximum);
 illegalState("Must be initialized to add elements");
 int size() { return unsupported(); }
Author:
jonathanl (shibo)
